text:
-Detective James Zadroga was
one of the first responders

and worked close to 500 hours at
the site, protected only by
a paper mask.

Although he quickly became
very ill, the police

department applied standard
sick leave
procedures to his case.

-At that time, if you looked at
him, you knew he was sick.

Anybody that looked at
him knew he was sick.

But he would go report to his
sick desk, and they would say,

you're not sick, go back
to work tomorrow.

And at first, he would
go back to work.

But then he got so sick, he
couldn't walk up the flight of
stairs to get into work.

He had to take the elevator up
to go one flight of stairs.
-But Zadroga couldn't work.

He couldn't play with
his baby daughter.
He couldn't breathe.
And it only got worse.
-He was on oxygen 24/7.

He was on three liters
of oxygen.

And later with four liters of
oxygen, and then it went up to
five towards the end.

I knew eventually, someday, I
would walk upstairs and find
him dead on the floor.

-James Zadroga had known he was
dying for a long time, as

he revealed in a letter
to his father.

-The dead, their deaths were
quick and painless, and mine
has just begun.
I can't breathe.
My throat is constantly sore.

I'm always coughing,
and headaches,
and sleepless nights.

Nightmares, anxiety, and visions
haunt me every day.

And I'm all alone except for
my dearest loved ones.
No one cares on the job.

They tell me I'm fine,
go back to work.

But truthfully, I haven't felt
this bad in my life.

-James Zadroga died on January
5, 2006, four and a half years

after he raced into the cloud
of dust. Pathologist Dr.

Breton did the autopsy
and agreed to
this exclusive interview.

-I was immediately
struck by the
enormous size of his lungs.

-Zadroga's lungs were three
times the normal weight.

When Breton looked at the slides
of the lung tissue, he
found out why.
The lungs were full of debris.

-These are the microscopic
sections of the lung.

It's opaque and pink here, and
these, I suspect, they are

dust. You see this fine
material there.
Look.
It's kind of look like fibers.

-The autopsy slides reveal
he had almost no
functioning lung tissue.

At least 80% of his lungs were
filled with granulomas, giant

cells that form around
foreign objects.

-So that the person is actually
being asphyxiated

with his own lung, because his
lung was being replaced by
these fine body granulomas.

When you tell me that the person
was helping in cleaning

Ground Zero, he was exposed to
all kind of fine debris.

And I find this in his lung, I
have to put them together.

-For the first time, a death had
been directly attributed
to the dust at Ground Zero.

But at New York City Hall, the
mayor's office viewed the
results as inconclusive.

Even five years later,
government officials are

reluctant to admit the link
between exposure at Ground
Zero and illness.

-If there were fears about
getting business up and going,

or if there were fears about
litigation and liability that

would have been very hard for
local and state and federal

government and other entities
to deal with, we could've
taken care of that.

To me, the most important
thing is, number
one, get to the truth.

And number two, take
care of people.

-Getting the truth and
protecting people are part of
the EPA's mandate.

But if the air at Ground Zero
was safe, why were so many
people getting sick?

Even some of EPA's own staff
doubted the agency's
assurances about safety.

Among them, senior policy
analyst Hugh Kaufman.

-Mrs. Whitman went on national
TV, smiled at camera, and told
everybody everything is safe.
And it wasn't.

-As they say, you know asbestos
was in there, is in
those buildings.
Lead is in those buildings.
There are the VOCs.

However, the concentrations are
such that they don't pose
a health hazard.

We're going to make sure
everybody's safe.
